Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I gained a lot of insights into the lives of the French population and how that even affected the rest of Europe - I really enjoyed learning about that!
Going into this class, I knew very little about the period between Napoleon's reign and the Franco-Prussian War, so I learned a whole lot about the social and political upheavals of the 1800s.
This course offered an overview of about a hundred years of French history, with particular attention to its social aspects.

History of France from 1789 to 1871, covering major political events and social changes. Merriman focuses heavily on social history, i.e. class politics, and much less so on diplomacy/military/cultural history.
This class really gave you an all around perspective of French History! You learn about a lot of specific details which I thought was great.
Class was super confusing at times. The Lecturer was very disorganized.

This course was very interesting and taught much about the factors that contributed to the French Revolution, the fall of the Bourbons, the fall of Louis Phillipe, and the rise of Napoleon III. The Paris commune was also a very interesting topic.

I finally learned the ins and outs of the French Revolution for real! I'd always been given a cursory glance of it in high school classes and other Yale courses, but it was so rewarding to finally REALLY learn it with a professor as great as Merriman. I think he also picked a super interesting time frame for the course, since we didn't just learn about the first Revolution everyone talked about, and learned about how the revolutions continued, much past 1848.
I developed a comprehensive knowledge of the French Revolution and all of the happenings that occurred from 1789 to 1871.

A thorough background of French history from 1789-1871 (but with some solid context of events ranging from 1750s -- the Firsts World War). Learned how to write a historiography + power through several books in a short period of time.
I learned about a key period of French history, how to write a research paper, and more. I also learned about where the best places to visit are and which restaurants to avoid.

The French Revolution: not a quick turn of events! Lasts until 1871 (and continued in the Spring!). It's a bloody, passionate, dynamic, exciting story that Professor Merriman brings to life. It's a microscope on Enlightenment thought and counter-revolutions to predominant trends.

Historical knowledge of France during the revolutionary period. Professor Merriman also taught me about the social history of ideas: how ideas were not so much formed in themselves, but existed in a wider context and affected change in that wider context.
history of france 1789-1875

I learned a great deal about France. The readings are superb and I learned a lot about the social and political dynamics surrounding France from the time of the Jacobins to the liberal empire. The essay was also a great way of delving deeper into the material since this is very much a survey course.
the history of france

I guess we were supposed to learn about France from 1789-1871, but I didn't really get much out of lectures or section, neither of which were at all organized or coherent. Section was bad, I think, because the TFs didn't get any guidance from Merriman on what to cover each week, but the terrible lectures had no excuse for being so bad. What I did learn came from conversations with my TF, paper research, and Wikipedia.
Deep understanding of the French revolution and social and cultural trends of this period
I was most interested in the intellectual history of France, and the important ideas for economics and political philosophy that came out of this era
Learning the nuances of the French revolutionary War and how this major event shaped France for decades to come.
I honed my analytical skills as a historian and writer. I also became better note-taker and improved my organizational skills given Professor Merriman's disorganized teaching style.
I gained the ability to analyze historical events and their importance. Moreover, I learned to write a paper and formulate a sound historical argument.

This class teaches you a lot about revolutionary French history, especially in the context of cultural trends (like the Enlightenment). Professor Merriman goes into highly specific details that will eventually give you a good idea of what exactly in France made the Revolution possible. 

I also learned how to skim readings because I unfortunately found section kind of uninteresting (though not by any fault of the TF).
I developed my writing and reading skills, as well as my research skills from the research paper that I completed. I gained an incredible amount of knowledge about French Revolutionary history.
A pretty thorough knowledge of France from 1789 to 1871
I was able to better my discussion section skills and broaden my knowledge of French history. This allowed me to channel my studying and helped me decide what my major is going to be.
Wide range of info (social, political, economic) impacts of the years of the French Revolution
Learned a lot about the french revolution, about which I knew very little before entering the course.
Great overview of French revolution
Lots!

Learn a ton about the various French Revolutions and Empires of the time period. A good mix of higher level political and ideological ideas and the more basic daily life aspects of the people of the period.
In half of the lecture, you learn about the history of France and the other half to learning about Merriman's life in France that will not show up on any test.
I know so much more about French history than I did before! I really had never studied past the first French revolution, so getting a broad introduction to 19th century French history was great.
Writing, reading
Lateral thinking when looking at historical events. How these events apply to present day situations.

French history is particularly rich and intriguing. Professor Merriman delivered a thorough course that allowed me to better capture the intricacies of a dense period in history, which determined the development of Europe. We learnt a lot about France and delved into topics that were of particular interest to me, such as drink and the Paris Commune. I enjoyed the books we had to read and learnt a lot about the social factors which influenced the Revolution and the events that followed it.
Knowledge on Revolutionary France
A great overview of French Revolution history
Learned about the French Revolution.
I gained a general overview of French history during the revolutionary history. The class did not focus on skill development.
This course helped me to understand France in a chronological timeline. It did a great job of telling social histories.
I learned a lot about France, Paris and Professor Merriman's favorite bars. Great class.
French language and culture, as well as the really interesting history of the Revolution.
Throughout this course I developed a deeper understanding of French history and more specifically the various themes and forces that shaped the French revolution.

I developed insights about the origins and causes of revolution in France from the ancien regime all the way to the Third Republic. I learned how to critically think about various trends and patterns that repeated throughout the time period and why they did.
Great overview of history of France.
Deeper understanding of 18th and 19th century France.
Strengths - lectures were super engaging and interesting, Professor Merriman is a super awesome lecturer

Professor Merriman has assigned some truly great texts, but sadly, there is no real way to read all of them if you are taking a full courseload. In terms of output, there is only one major assignment outside of the exams, which was really nice for someone whose other classes were quite writing-heavy.
Professor Merriman is a dynamic lecturer, but his lectures could be hard to follow sometimes, which made studying for the midterm and final harder.

This course is a lot of fun to take if you have an interest in history. Because the class covers such a narrow time frame, you learn a lot that you wouldn't in a much broader course. The course is also not a lot of work, and the lectures are made entertaining by Merriman's stories and friendly demeanor. The class also has an oral final exam which is just a 20 minute conversation with one of the TA's- this was a nice break from the rest of finals period and was definitely more enjoyable than spending 3 hours writing essays. 

On the flip side, the course sometimes felt a bit disorganized and many of the requirements weren't super clear. For me this didn't make a big difference because the course wasn't my top priority this semester, but if you care a lot about planning ahead this course might frustrate you.

This course is super amazing. I really enjoyed taking it. I love French history in general and Professor Merriman really taught me a lot I didn't know. It can go off on tangents at times, but overall he teaches you a lot of life skills along the way.

During lecture it sometimes felt as if material wasnt covered, and with stories being told all the time, it was difficult to contextualize things sometimes. 

The course overall though was super engaging and interesting

I liked both of the textbooks we used and the three novels we read (two of which were primary sources of Zola and Balzac). I would have loved more primary source reading, personally. One big strength was the reading. I rarely enjoy reading for a history class and mostly take them for the great seminars/lectures, but these readings I really enjoyed (maybe just because I love French history). Lecture was a huge highlight of the class. Prof Merriman is a legend for a reason. He sort of consciously avoids repeating anything from the reading, and instead lecture is like adult story time where Prof Merriman tells you all the weird little tidbits he's learned from studying France so closely for so long. He goes on these fun rambles that you just need to be okay enjoying. I think the people who didn't like this class were the ones too focused on having a super coherent lecture that mirrored the readingswith Prof Merriman, don't panic if he goes off the beaten path a bit; that's part of the fun!

Strengths: Topic itself is inherently fascinating. Merriman is extremely engaging in lecture, and he actually cares/recognizes when you attend lectures despite it being a bigger lecture. The keyword/big picture emails+Canvas updates before lecture were actually stupidly important. The TAs are fantastic, all of them. The paper allows you to explore something you're interested in. The class isn't an insane amount of work but you get out even more than you put in. 

Weaknesses: Honestly not a ton of weaknesses besides disorganization/lack of syllabus adherence. I can work with some freewheeling, but we were supposed to watch 2 (maybe 3?) movies over the semester which we never got to doing, lectures got shuffled around, etc.

The course covers a very interesting period in French history. The lectures are engaging, though they can meander. The exams are straightforward and very doable. Sections supplemented the material well.

Strengths include Professor Merriman, the material itself, and a History of Modern Europe (his textbook). It's a lifesaver for putting the sometimes segmented lectures together. Professor Merriman is a Yale gem and I haven't found a better lecturer at this school. Be prepared for a lot of reading.
Professor Merriman was not a focused lecturer. While obviously knowledgeable, he seemed to be all over the place during lectures and could do better if he had a tighter control over his material.

Strengths: not too much work, pretty interesting at times
Weaknesses: lectures are disorganized, not much structure or guidance for tests or papers

The readings are superb. Merriman's texts and the novels were great forays into the material. His lectures, on the other hand, were pretty much hit or miss. Sometimes they were incredibly engaging but oftentimes all over the place. Unless you go to office hours for the TF or Merriman, you'll have to rely heavily on the readings since his lectures often turn into tangential stories.
The lectures could be better outlined. I felt like a lot of the learning occurred through the readings.
the lectures were a bit out of order and the sections were very hardcore and difficult to connect back to the lectures

TERRIBLE LECTURES--honestly some of the worst I've taken at Yale. Readings were often tangential to the material and were terribly spaced throughout the course: one week, we'd read ten pages of some secondary source about Napoleon, and the next we would be assigned an entire 450-page book written in 1877 (L'Assommoir). Sections were not very useful, but judging from conversations with the TFs that was only because Merriman gave them no guidance on what to cover each week. And if you're thinking the TFs should have known from what Merriman went over in lecture, you ought to attend one of his lectures; no one has any clue what he's talking about, and it's a complete mess.
strengths are merriman and the material. weaknesses are the lectures can be all over the place
The lecture was a little disjointed and difficult to follow bc Professor Merriman improvises a lot in class. Otherwise it was a pretty interesting course
Readings from this course were fantastic--including a fascinating book from Merriman himself. Classes always had great discussions and TFs were highly engaging.

Strengths: fascinating material, Professor Merriman (though he's not for everyone), had a fantastic TA, light reading load

Weaknesses: disorganized (that's just Professor Merriman though, he's a fantastic professor), odd assignments (every now and then Merriman would assign a novel to read that no one actually read)
The course material is interesting but the lectures are hard to follow.

Strengths: I loved Professor Merriman's storytelling. He makes lectures very engaging to listen to both with his presentation of the historical content but also with his fun commentary about French culture. Also, the paper is kind of fun to write because you are given so much leeway with regards to picking a topic. 

Weaknesses: I felt that sections did not contribute much at all to this class. My TF was great and helped us contextualize the information with discussions about art, architecture, and literature, but from talking to other people also taking this class, this was not the case in all sections. TFs had very different ideas of how to conduct sections, with varying results.

While most of the material was very interesting, I don't think the course did a good job explaining why 18th French history was important. I was left wondering: how should we apply our understanding of this period to contemporary politics? How does this course relate to other disciplines, subjects, and our larger liberal arts education? Why does any of this matter?

It is a very informative course about a very hectic time period. I learned a great deal from this course - from discussion sections, lectures and readings. I am not sure how this course could be improved.
Lectures sometimes felt a little scattered and unclear.
I think there could be a couple more essays that are required as a way to understand what is necessary in historical papers (for students who don't have a ton of experience with this).

Merriman is so friendly/sweet but hard to follow as a lecturer. He clearly knows so much and cares so much, but he almost has too many stories, and so you lose the thread of the actual history he is trying to teach. Most of what I learned was through googling. Because of this, studying for the tests-- which would be easy if class notes were sufficient-- took extra work.
Great that bullet points for lecture are sent out before, and Merriman's lecture style is fun and engaging.
Lectures could at times be a little scattered. I felt like I had to teach myself lots of material before midterm/finals.
Loved how engaging lecture was and sections were also well led. Overall LOVED the course.
Strengths -- really interesting content. Weaknesses -- Merriman rambles a lot, you end up making a bunch of random notes that have no coherence.
lectures were very scattered and did not cover materials on the exams

This was an interesting class, however, the lecture was very disorganized and not always helpful in learning the information. Lots of times it was useful to look up important people and events because it was not discussed in class.

Strengths-great lectures
Weakness-disorganized
The paper was a little too unrelated to the course.

The material was overall very relevant and interesting. Professor Merriman is an expert in the field of French history and he was successfully able to share his knowledge in a clear and digestible way. The readings were also in the most part interesting, and they allowed students to get a real sense of what was happening in France/Europe during the discussed timeframe. I think the course lacked a bit of structure at times: we were never really sure what was expected of us on exams/assignments, and lectures were sometimes scattered. I would simply recommend adding a layer of structure and making clear how we should improve. But Professor Merriman is notoriously anti-system, so I doubt much will change :)
Lectures could be more organized
Weakness is that theres no grades before the drop deadline
Merriman is the man.

Strength: teacher knowledge, subject matter, course theme continuity

Weakness: tangential lectures with a more rambling style
The lectures are engaging, but they lack structure. Because of this, it would have been helpful to have a specific list of terms to be responsible for on the midterm.

This course was strong. I think the lists of course terms for each lecture was helpful, although maybe these documents could have more structure. The final paper crept up on everyone, so maybe it would be useful to require a draft or proposal due in the middle of the semester. The course overall was great!
Lecture could be a bit rambling. It would be helpful if we got scans of the textbook readings from the library.
Strengths were reqd readings, they were all pretty interesting. Weaknesses may be the fact that there is no prompt for the reseaech paper.

I thought strengths of the first half of the course were the resources and repetition. Between lecture, section, and the books, students had many resources to call on to reinforce their learning. In terms of books, the second half of the class did not offer resources that were as helpful unfortunately.
Very strong course. Could perhaps be given a little more time to do the three big readings. Other than that, very good course.
Great lecture and section!
The lectures could be structured better but at the same time this is Merriman's style.
Yes, of course!! Amazing lecture and you will learn so many new and interesting things. Even things that you already know will be presented in a new way!

I would recommend this course to anyone who genuinely wants to get a solid understanding of French history, with an emphasis on politics and social/intellectual movements, and doesn't mind a significant amount of reading.
Yes

Yes, French history in this period is intrinsically interesting, and Professor Merriman's lectures are generally fun. However, the difficulty of the class may sneak up if you don't do the readings or take good lecture notes.
I would definitely- it was not a lot of work, and the lectures were entertaining and you learn a lot of interesting things if you pay attention.

Yes - take it! Merriman is a great professor (as long as you learn to enjoy his rambling), and has a lot of great anecdotes and insights into French history. The workload isn't bad either (midterm, essay, and verbal final exam). It pairs well with his European Civ lecture, so don't be afraid to take this if you've already taken a course with him. Knowing some European history (whether from AP Euro or elsewhere) might be helpful, especially at the beginning of the class.
Yes! Great history course! If you are not super interested in history, this is a great class for you as well because it has interesting material that people would have fun learning.
I would not unless it changed. The content is interesting but the class is highly disorganized to the point where it becomes a lot more challenging to do well than it should be.
Yes, Merriman is a fantastic professor and I would recommend his courses to everyone.

Definitely. All of Merriman's lectures are a fun and wild ride, but I think this one is a particular gem, mostly because the French Revolution is just so cool to learn about. It's like dramatic reality TV before there was reality TV. A few things to note: Merriman lectures about whatever he thinks is cool and NOT the reading really so you need to be independent in that regard, sometimes he rambles and it gets confusing but everything he says is super cool, this is one of those awful finals periods classes that has a paper due the last week of class and then a final so keep that in mind when planning your life. The course felt backloaded in terms of work because all we had early in the semester was the midterm. Also, there is an optional oral final exam that I personally loved, because you wrap up the class by studying the important points and then talking about them with a TF. My oral exam was difficult personally, because the TF sort of grilled me, but for a lot of my friends it was super super chill. Just be sure you really know the material (you get the questions ahead of time) and be prepared for a little back and forth with the TF once you answer the question. This was my favorite class this semester, mostly because I personally like Prof Merriman's style, but mostly because I love this period of French history and it's something I've always really wanted to know about. So I think during shopping period, gauge if you are up for the professor's kookiness and also ask yourself if you are really interested in this area of French history.
I would recommend this course to another student. I thoroughly enjoyed learning about French history and I really enjoyed getting to know Merriman.

Absolutely. Whether or not you're interested in the content (American History focus in the History department here, to be frank I couldn't care less about France), Merriman is an icon. The lectures aren't always relevant to the midterm/final, but the broader themes he talks about during lecture and obscure facts do occasionally pop up on the midterm/final.

Merriman also tends to rant sometimes and go off on tangents. Merriman is one of, if not the, most engaging professors at all of Yale when he just goes off on a tangent -- his speeches about his friends' weddings, the Yale alumni cruises, his time in Catholic school in Oregon, his time in the archives in France, the time he was a diehard Communist (don't worry, he still is too), comments on the current state of America and France (currently, the Yellow Vest protests are going on in France, he had some interesting thoughts), and more are seriously legendary/memorable and you get just as much out of those as you do from the stuff he says. 

I recommend taking this class for 1) a funny, engaging lecture with a legend in his field and 2) a relatively low commitment course. If you take this course, GO TO LECTURES. Short of you having a midterm/final the same day, go to all the lectures -- it's worth it, even though ~1/3-1/2 the class will stop going after the midterm. He's worth it. The TAs are great too (but that varies year to year I'm sure).
I would recommend this course to another student. The material is interesting and Professor Merriman is an engaging lecturer who clearly knows his stuff.
It's a terrific course. Regrettably the oversubscription made the class a little less personal, but still Professor Merriman is a Yale gem and the material is incredible.

Only take it if you're interested in the French revolutionary period, and, even then, I'm sure you might find other courses which can deal with this same content in a better fashion. I wouldn't recommend it.
Wouldn't necessarily recommend the course if you're looking for an intellectual challenge or structured class. But it wasn't too much work
Ya. It's not a bad course. Great for a fifth spot.
Yes, it's a fun and easy overview of Revolutionary French history.
yes, because the lectures were fun and interesting
Nope. Disorganized lectures and irrelevant readings led to me learn most of what I needed to know for exams from Wikipedia. In my book, that means it's a bad class. Don't take it.

I was extremely disappointed with this course, especially after having generally enjoyed Merriman's lecture course on European History. It requires almost no effort or engagement to do well. The grade is a midterm (if you study the terms sheet it's easy), final (the questions are given beforehand with an oral option), and 8 page paper on a topic of your choice. The first half is actually interesting if you know little about the French Revolution and Napoloen. But from about 1815 onward, you learn almost nothing besides the names of the most important leaders and the couple relevant regime changes. I think you could summarize the entire second half of the course in about 15 minutes. And Merriman's lectures, which are already extremely disjointed and tangential really go off the rails here. He's completely unstructured and nearly impossible to follow in class, and so I often left frustrated. Really disappointing class taught by someone who can be so interesting. There are much better history classes to take at Yale, don't waste your time.
would recommend because merriman is an awesome professor, and the material is easy to understand. Good for non-history majors.
Yes, I think it's a fun and laid-back course, easy to do well in it.
Yes, learning from Professor Merriman is an opportunity you shouldn't pass up.

Absolutely take this class: incredible professor, interesting topics, light workload, lenient and fair grading. Fair warning: Professor Merriman takes a little getting used to. He is clearly a true expert and knows everything, though his lectures can be pretty disorganized and he goes on lots of tangents about his various trips to France, how much he drinks at various bars, and how many failed weddings he has been the best man at. His style just takes a little to get used to. He's incredibly entertaining, always made me laugh like 10 times a lecture.
I would recommend this course because of how interesting the material is and how important French history during this time period is to understanding historical events later on.

I would definitely recommend this class to another student who wants to attend fun lectures and get to know Professor Merriman's eccentric personality and style of teaching. His passion for the subject really shines through in his lectures, which is wonderful. He's also a funny person.

However, the readings only really supplement the class (and I felt that some were overkill) and section feels like a waste of time. That said I took this class Credit/D/Fail so it was a lower commitment to me than my classmates. 

Overall I would recommend it, but sometimes the syllabus feels a little irrelevant or illogical as Professor Merriman will just take things his own way (which isn't a bad thing).
I would recommend this course to another student. The workload is definitely manageable, and I learned a great deal about a very interesting time period.

I'd recommend it - learning from Merriman during lecture is a pretty cool experience even though you have to put up with him being scattered or unclear sometimes. The period of history is also very interesting. The oral final exam was a great experience - much better than a written final could ever have been.
I most definitely would recommend this course to another student because of the energetic nature of Professor Merriman and the knowledgable TAs he brings along with him.

If you are interested in the topic, definitely take it. I took this class mainly because I needed a humanities credit and I wanted to take a class with Professor Merriman. He is THE BEST - his passion for the material is contagious and his lectures include a lot of stories which keep it interesting.
I would if you are interested in France or need a pre-industrial credit for history.
Absolutely
Merriman clearly is passionate about his material, but I'm unsure if looking back I would have taken this course as opposed to another lecture. I didn't get much from it.
YES. Great European history course taught by a great professor.

This course is definitely a mixed bag. It really depends on the TA you get - my TA was totally lovely and so awesome. I would say the hardest parts of it are the midterm and the paper. For the midterm exam, you need to have done all the reading and paid attention very closely in class. For the final, it's a bit easier, because you get given the questions beforehand and can prepare as much as you want. In this class we had to read a ton of books - tbh like no one reads them. The class was full of the typical "party crowd" and finance kids, but many realized a few weeks in that the course really isn't as easy as expected.
not a gut, oral final was harder than made out to be and didnt cover lots of course material. midterm fucked everyone.
Good history credit, if you have done well in other history classes you will do well in this class. It can be a bit boring at times. Yeah
It's an alright class for learning about France but very disorganized and that makes it harder to learn the info

I took this credit-d and I think it was a great class to do that for because I could go to Professor Merriman's very interesting and engaging lectures, but I didn't have to worry too much about keeping up with the readings. That being said the midterm was fairly difficult and included relatively obscure questions but then the final was extremely fair and straightforward. And then we just had to write one 7-10 page paper which is also totally reasonable. Overall, I found the class to be quite interesting because I had almost no knowledge of 19th century French history, but that period is fascinating!
Yes-very interesting
Rambling lectures but kind and passionate lecturer.
Professor Merriman is an interesting lecturer. Take it purely because of his wild stories and opinions.

Yes, I would recommend this course. It was relatively low stress and very interesting, especially to people who are interested in European history. I was lucky to have Maggie as a section leader because she is really brilliant and helped us make very solid timelines, which helped with the tests.
Decent way to get a HU credit
Yes for anyone interested in French history! Merriman is great.
Yes. John Merriman is great.
Yes, but be ready to throw yourself into the course material.
Yes, it has a light course load and is about an interesting subject that a lot of people know little about.

Take this course if you're really interested in France  if you aren't, and take it as just another history course, it may not interest you as much as you had thought. Low reading and workload, and Merriman's lectures are entertaining.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in French history or seeks a class that is somewhat relaxed.
I would recommend this course because French history is so interesting. The class is relaxing yet still intellectually stimulating.
Yes! It's definitely a lighter history course but it was fun and I learned a lot.
Absolutely!! Fantastic way to learn about the history of France.
I would recommend this course to any student trying to build a deeper foundation in their historical knowledge.
Yes. It is a very interesting course with a manageable workload and a professor who is truly passionate about the material and whose passion is nothing short of infectious.
Yes, must take Yale course! Merriman is iconic!
Yes.
yes
